Twenty-five years ago this week, NBC introduced us to the Huxtables on primetime TV.
They were educated, professional, upper middle-class and black.
For Teresa Wiltz, the ""Cosby Show"" was mainstream America's first successful introduction to an upper-class black family.
And that alone was revolutionary.
But along with folksy humor and colorful sweaters, the show was a platform for Bill Cosby's particular brand of activism.
